channel.title: One Mountain Bike
channel.description: A tear down and build up story

item.title: 5 Essential Articles Of MTB Attire
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
You do not need to break the bank to ride your mountain bike. You just need to be comfortable, safe and halfway stylish.

And look, you can even wear baggy pants like me and still get away with it. It doesn't have to be perfect. Click the image above to zoom in and look at my pants. Waaaaaaaaaay too baggy.

Feet

Starting with your feet, get something comfortable. Just look at the variety of cool shoes. I can't speak to clipless because I ride flats, but I imagine there are comfortable clipless as well. I ride these simple 5.10s. They don't have to get much fancier.

Outfit

You should have a few pairs of shorts for riding in warmer conditions. If you plan on riding when it's cold some pants would be a good thing.

As far as shirts go, I get away with your just average athletic shirts, but I do have a few nice biking shirts I will wear on long bike days. For layers, I wear longer versions of the same athletic shirts. One day I'm going to step up into a real athletic flannel, but for now I'm wearing just a normal cotton flannel. It's not the best for mountain biking admittedly.

Gloves

I'd get a pair of full-length gloves that have touch screen capability so you can use your smartphone without taking off your gloves. I'd also get some regular every day riding gloves as well like these Rangers for instance.

Eye protection

I have some nice Fox Vue goggles that double as my snowboarding goggles. Getting some with replaceable lenses is nice if you really scratch them up. Mine also support tear-away clear lenses which is also nice because I do not want to replace the expensive lense underneath that often.

Helmet

I have a half-shell like a TLD A3 that I use pretty much every day I ride. For more extreme riding, like downhill bike park riding, I always wear my full-face. I have had some bad crashes and this full-face has saved my teeth. Something like the TLD D4 or Stage works great.

Bonus

If you want extra protection while riding more extreme terrain, here's what I have for body protection. Nice set of knee pads, elbow sleeves and a chest and spine protector. You can go more rigid than what I have, but I'm going for all day comfort most of the time.

item.title: Top 10 Reasons Why Mountain Biking Is Good For You
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Yup, it's good for you to be outside on a bike if you can! Check out all the reasons why it's awesome for your heart and your mind.

Full-body workout: Mountain biking is a great way to get a full-body workout. You use your legs to pedal, your arms to steer and control the bike, and your core to maintain your balance.

Builds strength and endurance: Regular mountain biking helps to build strength and endurance in your legs, back, and arms, making it easier to tackle more challenging trails.

Cardiovascular health: Mountain biking is a great way to get your heart pumping, which can help improve your cardiovascular health and reduce your risk of heart disease.

Low-impact exercise: Mountain biking is a low-impact exercise that is easy on your joints, making it a great option for people of all ages and fitness levels.

Mental health benefits: Mountain biking can be a great stress reliever and can help to boost your mood and reduce anxiety and depression.

Burns calories: Mountain biking is a great way to burn calories and lose weight. Depending on your intensity and duration, you can burn anywhere from 500 to 1000 calories per hour.

Improves balance and coordination: Mountain biking requires a lot of balance and coordination, so regular riding can help to improve your overall balance and coordination.

Builds bone density: Mountain biking is a weight-bearing exercise, which helps to build bone density and reduce the risk of osteoporosis.

Enhances flexibility: Mountain biking requires a lot of flexibility and range of motion, especially in your legs and hips, so regular riding can help to enhance your flexibility.

Fun and engaging: Mountain biking is a fun and engaging form of exercise that can help you stay motivated and committed to your fitness goals.

item.title: 15 Best GoPro Settings For Mountain Biking
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Yeah, yeah, agreed, it all varies by personal preference. You ride at night? You ride in low light. Ok go with different EV comp and ISO settings.

Now as a starting point, I'd like to highlight that I listened to some veterans (Skills with Phil, Jordan Boostmaster) out there talking about their settings in their own GoPros. I like what they did so I tried to emulate it. I don't have their exact settings, not because I'm better than them, I just didn't want to do post-editing like they do or fuss with other things like light conditions. I just wanted something that you can set and forget 95% of the time.

So for everyone riding in normal daytime conditions here you! This is on a GoPro 10 so if you have let's say an 8, your hypersmooth options may vary, but this will get you close.

I also run some windsocks on the microphones to help cut down on high-speed wind noise. I just cut it out of foam, nothing fancy (check out this photo).

Resolution: 4K

Frames per second: 30
I'd like to go to 24fps, but afraid it will be too chunky. High frames rates supposedly make you look like you’re riding a lot slower than you are. That sucks, I ride slow enough as it is. Ha!

Lens: SuperView
Superview also tends to make you look like you're going slower than you are or so I read somewhere. Plus there's a bit of the fish eye lens effect. However, lots of folks run Superview+Boost (Hypersmooth) and it looks amazing. Maybe they just go 2x faster than me.

Hypersmooth 4.0: Boost
High has a 10% image crop. If you use Boost, you might want to go with Superview instead of Wide lens since Boost will have a lot of image cropping. Interesting video comparing the two.

Zoom: 1.0

Bit Rate: High
Get a 128GB or higher card and put this on high. It should help getting rid of rough edges in your frames. Also, good to have as HIGH if you do post-processing like in final cut pro.

Shutter: Auto
Cameras have apertures, GoPro does not. So let GoPro auto adjust for moving through trees. If you wan to mess with it, do it somewhere still that has no change in light.

EV Comp: -1.0
Under-expose to capture more detail in bright daylight.

White Balance: 5500K
This brightens a little which helps in high contrast areas. Going up on the Kelvin scale means you are going "cooler".

ISO Min: 100
When you add in ISO you are adding in fake light which is additional noise. So you want this to be as low as you can get away with, hence 100, while keeping the best image quality possible.

ISO Max: 1600
High ISO settings are useful at night or in extremely low light situations. That is rare in MTB so you should be able to do 1600 max.

Sharpness: Low
Sharpness could cause worse video quality (especially in low light scenarios) because it's your GoPro trying to automatically sharpen an image. The tradeoff just isn't worth it as supposedly it's not that good at sharpening anyway.

Color: Natural
Let GoPro do the work unless you like to edit colors heavily in post-production.

RAW Audio: Off
GoPro will record a separate unfiltered audio track which is good if you want to do a lot of post-editing and match it up with your original footage. Most don't do this so let GoPro do the work.

Wind: On
I've tried it with it OFF and it's been a mess. Leave it ON because it does help reduce wind noise significantly!

item.title: Why do you need a bike stand?
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
A reasonable (doesn't necessarily have to break the bank) bike stand is a useful tool for a number of reasons. Snag one off my tools page.

Storage: A bike stand provides a stable and secure place to store your bike, keeping it upright and preventing it from falling over. This is especially useful if you have limited storage space, as it allows you to store your bike vertically and take up less floor space.

Maintenance: A bike stand allows you to work on your bike more easily and safely, by holding it in a stable position while you make repairs or adjustments. This can make tasks such as changing a tire, adjusting brakes, or cleaning and lubricating the chain much easier.

Cleaning: A bike stand can also make it easier to clean your bike, as it holds it in a stable position and allows you to rotate the pedals while you clean the chain and other parts.

Overall, a bike stand is a useful tool for any mountain biker (or any other biker), whether you're a casual rider or a serious biker who enjoys performing your own bike maintenance.

item.title: My MTB Bucket List
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Globally, there are places I want to ride like Whistler in Canada and La Fenasosa in Spain.

However, even just inside the United States where I live there are plenty of unchecked boxes for me.

I get ideas from all of you out there in the wild on YouTube so appreciate the tips!

I maintain a sort of up to date list of where I have been.

And in the immediate North Carolina area, I've managed to sneak in a bunch of mileage at the following trails.

Airline Bike Park
Anne Springs
Backyard Trails
Ballantyne District Park
Brown Mill Mountain Bike Trail
Cedar Valley Bike Park
Col. Francis Beatty Park
Fisher Farm Park
Mazeppa Park
Mountain Creek Park
Park Road Park
Poston Park
Purser Hulsey Park
Renaissance Park
Rocky Branch Park
Rocky River Trail
Salisbury Community Park
Sherman Branch
Southwest District Park
USNWC

item.title: My MTB Crashes
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
I've got some of my crashes on video, but not all of them. That's a shame because they are entertaining!

I've broken a lot of bike parts, almost lost an eye, cracked a tooth and yet enjoyed every minute of it. My friends have suffered a concussion and some broken bones and egos as well. But here's a video list of some of ones we did capture.

Rock Creek Crash
Nasty that wasn't the result of any bike failure, just a me failure :)
- Broke left thumb in 2 places
- Broke 3 right upper ribs
- Broke collarbone in 6 large fragments and 12 tiny fragments
- Busted my chin open
- Concussion
- You can check out my road to recovery here


Beech & Sugar Crashes
- Dan's Black Mamba crash several POVs @ 4:23 in video
- Matt's Black Mamba crash @ 6:16 in video
- Scott's Black Mamba crash @ 6:41 in video
- Matt's Sugar Gap landing bail @ 20:07 in video


Paint It Black (PIB)

Roll The Dice Crash


Sugar Mountain Gnarnia Crash


Boneyard Crash


Tumbleweed Crash


Dark Hollow Crashes


BYT Gap Crash
Broke my bike on this one! Was down for a good 15 minutes. Ha!


And plenty of near misses like this one at BYT

item.title: Scariest Thing I've Done On Mountain Bike
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Without question it's the Red Bull drop at Windrock.

There is nothing like it. The rush is intense.

High speed, commitment and a very, very narrow landing on loose rock and dirt. Getting to the drop itself is no joke either full of high-speed bumpy gnar.

Hold onto your butt because once you are on the bridge there is no turning back!

Unfortunately, that side of the mountain was destroyed in a mudslide in November, 2022. I learned it will not be rebuilt. That is really sad as it was an iconic feature of the mountain. There is a new jump line however that will lead you down to the side of where the massive step-up is after the drop. The step-up is being demolished as well after the last Tennessee Whip-Off contest in early 2023.

item.title: Check Out My Bucket List. Am I Missing Anything?
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
I got a list of all the places I want to hit in my lifetime.

It's going to take a while. Ha!

Is there anywhere you've been that a reasonable amateur like myself should go that is not on my list?

item.title: 6 Easy Steps On How I Created This Marvel Comics Looking Video
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
It's an old school black and white looking comic book feel.

Totally unnecessary. Totally ridiculous. Yet awesome. Ha!

Alright well here's what you gotta do.

STEP 1
Create awesome footage by sending something big. The bigger the better as it will pop out. Here, Matt is following me down Southeast Style at Ride Kanuga in Hendersonville, NC.

STEP 2
Put it in an editor. In this case, I downloaded it off my GoPro onto my Mac and used Final Cut Pro (FCP). I have Adobe After Effects, but haven't checked if this works as easily there.

STEP 3
In FCP, open your Effects panel and search for Comic Ink and apply it on top of your video. You can adjust various settings to make it less or more comic-feel looking.

STEP 4
Export the video for YouTube. Here are my settings in case it helps!

STEP 5
In YouTube studio editor, apply a soundtrack of your choice. You can alternatively download some tracks, like the one I used here, into FCP and apply it there as part of your video you upload to YouTube.

STEP 6
Let me know if you have any questions!

item.title: Tips For Nervous Breakdown MTB Trail
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Not a mental nervous breakdown, but the trail marked as a pro jumpline Nervous Breakdown

SPEED
A couple pedals into the first jump and you're set on speed for rest of jumps until you get to the wooden drop

3RD JUMP
It's a hip so let it throw the back end out to the left just a little

TREE STUMP JUMP
The tree stump is a half a brake if anything and just float over it

WHALE TAIL
Grab a small finger of rear brake before the first whale tail so you don't send that too fast

THE BIGGET GAP
Just before the right to left hip is the biggest jump on the line. You definitely need to slow down with two quick rear brake jabs let's say or you will send it too deep into the berm. If you sense you might be coming up a tad short don't worry there's a case pad. You can also pull a little on the takeoff lip to get a little more airtime.

THE HIP
So you need to really rail that berm fast to keep your speed or you will case the hip. Even if you case it though it's not a big deal.

THE DROP
I'm in. my 4th of 12th hardest gear on this line and just get a pedal stroke or two and you'll nail the drop fine. It's a weird abrupt landing if you send it too deep. The trail builders made the case pad a little more user friendly in case you come up short.

Enjoy!

item.title: My 2023 Mountain Biking Goals
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
It's good to have goals. I think. Right? That's what "they" say.

So here goes mine. I am keeping track!

BICYCLE GOALS FOR 2023

  • Ride a true DH bike
  • Big Ash at @snowshoemtn
  • Stampede at @riderockcreek
  • Air Supply at @jarrods_place
  • A-Line at @whistlerbikeprk

NOTABLES FOR 2022

  • RedBull Drop at Windrock
  • SEStyle at Kanuga
  • Hemlock Double at Kanuga
  • Road gap at Beech (BEECH NIXED IT)
  • Sugar gap at Sugar
  • Avery gap at Pisgah (DIDN'T GET TO IT)

NOTABLES FOR 2021

  • Drop The Hammer at Coler
  • Nervous Breakdown at Cedar Valley
  • Free Ride at BYT
  • Big Brutas at Kanuga
  • 6 features on SEStyle (FAIL)
  • 5 second wheelie
  • 5 second manual (FAIL)
  • Rent a turbo levo eBike

NOTABLES FOR 2020

  • First air in May at USNWC
  • 1st bike park at Kanuga with my son
  • Bumblebee gaps at BYT
  • 5 big crashes and 1 face scar
  • Many broken bike components

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Here are the top 5 key points from the provided text:
1. The author has set goals for their bike riding adventures, including specific trails to conquer. 2. They keep track of notable achievements and failures from each year. 3. The author has experienced several crashes and broken bike components along the way. 4. They rented an eBike in 2021. 5. The author values the importance of having goals to strive towards.

item.title: A New MTB Checkbox
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Definitely the steepest lips and jumps I'd ever done!

Location: Ride Kanuga in Hendersonville, NC

Here's my notes in case they help anyone else!

  • Gear - 4th of 12th hardest gear entire time. I tried 3rd and just found it too tough to get enough pedal revolutions. I made it off the drop, but it felt wonky. So I stuck with 4th from then on and sent the entire line with it in 4.
  • Container Drop - I do a slight pull off the container lip as I'm going off after 3 or 4 pedals
  • 1st Gap - Easy, just a floater no real pull needed, but I found it easier to stay on the left side so that I could enter the first hip a bit straighter (since I'm not good at hip jumps)
  • 1st Hip - If anything, a tiny brake tap, but for me, since I don't go very high I used no brakes and sent it perfectly
  • 2nd Hip - I get 1 full pedal in after the first hip and the second one is just fine. I stay on the inside so I don't have to send it far and high.
  • Road Gap - Super fun, just do a pull over the lip and pedal a couple of times into it. You can use that extra speed when entering the next berm in order to send the iron ramp.
  • Iron Ramp - I need better jump technique to really send this properly, but it's smooth. Just hit it full speed no brakes. I did not pedal into it, but probably could have if I wanted to send it higher with a bit more jump technique.

item.title: Another New MTB Checkbox
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Dark Hollow road gap at Rock Creek

The team built a new catch berm that helps you keep speed. So maybe after the catch berm a safety pedal, but you really do not need any pedals. You have enough speed.

Enjoy!

item.title: RedBull Drop Is Getting Demolished
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
On one hand I'm so thankful to have captured this moment of pure joy and adrenaline with a mountain biking friend of mine. On the other hand, I'm so sad to learn it's getting torn down permanently sometime after March 2023.

Bummer.

A storm took down the ravine entry into the drop itself so they are going to take it down after the TN whip-off contest. The step-up used in the contest is also getting the axe.

In its place the Redneck Ravine with the massive log cannon launcher is taking its place as the tail of the trail.

item.title: GoPro 101 For Mountain Bikers: The Essentials Of Resolution, Lens, HyperSmooth!
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
For all of my settings, click here, but here's the essentials in this video.

Get at least this right and you'll be on your way to quality videos in no time.

Resolution: 4K

Frames per second: 30
I’d like to go to 24fps, but afraid it will be too chunky. High frames rates supposedly make you look like you’re riding a lot slower than you are. That sucks, I ride slow enough as it is. Ha!

Lens: SuperView
Superview also tends to make you look like you’re going slower than you are or so I read somewhere. Plus there’s a bit of the fish eye lens effect. However, lots of folks run Superview+Boost (Hypersmooth) and it looks amazing. Maybe they just go 2x faster than me.

Hypersmooth 4.0: Boost
High has a 10% image crop. If you use Boost, you might want to go with Superview instead of Wide lens since Boost will have a lot of image cropping. Interesting video comparing the two.

item.title: ♢♢ Still Progressing Slowly But Surely Stampede At Rock Creek
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
The practice is paying off.

Stampede is a double black diamond pro line at Rock Creek in Zirconia, NC.

item.title: 🟦 Tumbleweed An Excellent Intermediate Trail
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
This is a fantastic blue trail that is perfect for beginner and intermediate riders to ramp up their progression on the bike!

It has a new entrance as well.

It used to start going to the right whereas the double black pro line Stampede went to the left. But now you can go on Stampede's first jump and right after that jump split off to the right and get back on Tumbleweed.

If you want an extra challenge, take the new starting line.

item.title: Mountain Biking Crash And Collarbone Surgery
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
Summary of the incident video

April 21, 2023
Spectacular mountain biking crash resulting in broken left thumb, 3 broken right ribs and broken right collarbone. Drove myself from the parking lot at the course to the ER. Then my buddy drove me 3 hours from the ER to my house. I threw up 3 or 4 times outside his car on the way home. The morphine from the ER had done its job. I made it home! The ER said all of the broken bones should heal on their own without surgery, but to see an ortho for an opinion.

April 22 - 23
The pain is intense. I emailed the doc asking for a referral to an ortho on Sunday. I heard back saying they were going to make a referral and I should hear something ASAP.

April 26
5 days after the crash I hadn't received a phone call so I emailed my doc. The doc said that was weird and to call and make an appointment directly. That's frustrating. I just wasted nearly a whole week waiting! Next time, don't sit by idly, go after it on your own.

April 27
I call ortho and get in same day for thumb. They took x-rays and said it broken, but should heal on its own.

April 28
I got in the next day for my shoulder. They took x-rays and told me how bad it was. Broken in 5 or 6 large pieces and 10 or 12 smaller pieces depending on how small you go. Surgery was required.

April 29
My wife took out my stitches from my chin. I could definitely feel it when she pulled out chin hairs instead of stitches. Ha!

May 1
I got to meet the actual surgeon. He confirmed it's really bad and said I could not wait. He. bumped me up his schedule and let me on my way. The pain is annoying and sometimes intense so I really wanted to get this done. I got a call that afternoon saying surgery was 7:15a.m. Wednesday May 3. I'm excited.

May 3
Collarbone surgery. Had to be there at 5:45a.m. Surgery started on time and was expected to last from 7:15 to 8:45 at max. It lasted until 9:45a.m.. Once inside, the damage was more severe than anticipated. The burning sensation in my shoulder was gone for the most part after surgery almost immediately. I could feel any movement of my arm would create a uncomfortable sensation. It's a feeling that I could describe as if my arm fell asleep. Keeping it in the sling was the solution.

May 4
Pain level is not bad, must be the painkillers. Slept for a few hour off and on taking pain killers through the night.

May 5
Pain level was the worst this day. Slept for a few hour off and on taking pain killers through the night.

May 6 - 7
Pain level not too bad. Starting to take myself off pain meds. Although I had to pop 1 or 2 pain pills here or there over the course of a couple of days for pain.

May 8
6th day after surgery marks my 17th day after the crash. I sneezed for the 2nd time since the crash and it felt ok. Man, I was worried it was going to be incredibly painful. I also slept terrible having not taken any pain killers. I wasn't in pain, but my lower back kept waking me up every hour with uncomfortableness.

May 10
1 week after the surgery. Put on a short sleeved workout shirt by myself. Felt awesome to put on a short sleeve. Progress!!

May 13
Woke up feeling A+ better compared to earlier days post surgery.

May 14
Drove a small block around the neighborhood without a thumb brace or sling on! Wife sat shotgun. Felt great to be behind the wheel!

May 16
A day under 2 weeks since my surgery, I have my first post-op checkup. It was supposed to be a few days prior, but got pushed.
Collarbone - gotta wear the sling for another couple of weeks as the bone hasn't started to fuse together yet per the x-ray.
Thumb - this is a concern, took an x-ray of my right thumb to see if it matched the weird looking x-ray of my left. Hoping to avoid surgery. They are stinting me for another couple of weeks, but when not active want me to take it off and aggressively start moving the thumb.
Ribs - seem to be healing, sneezing doesn't hurt anymore and we didn't even discuss it at the visit.

May 20
Got my ring on my finger finally. Ha. Swelling has subsided.

May 22
First day off the couch and into my actual bed. Man, it is way more comfortable. I still have some lower back pain, but I quit ibuprofen a few days ago and any stronger meds quite a while before then.

May 30
Back at a day shy of 4 weeks from surgery and got to remove the sling! Excited for that. Very uncomfortable to have to wear that all the time. I went for a walk and it already feels better. Doc said there are early signs of bone healing from the x-rays.

May 31
Hand doc said the fractures will heal on their own and the only concern they have is the range of motion. No surgery required though!! The range of motion seems to be limited by a combination of early arthritis and a possible prior injury. So it sounds like I may get a little more range of motion back, but what I have now is what I have. Good enough I suppose. Wish it was a little better, but the other option is risky surgery to remove scar tissue (my guess) and they haven't suggested surgery as an option at all. So I'm leaving it to the doc for their opinion which is keep working on range of motion and leave as is.

June 2
Finally got my heart rate up! First day of fast walking and not old man slow walking. It's a small achievement, but I'll take it!

June 7
Exactly 5 weeks after surgery and I'm feeling better than ever. I can still feel where the collarbone (or my new plate) is attached to my sternum and I have a little shoulder joint pain here and there, but overall no biggie. I can fully raise and extend my right arm behind my back, above my head and do various exercises. I'm not running yet or even jogging, but I'm fast walking. Progress!! My thumb is a mess and I guess it will just be what it is, a limited range of motion.

June 12
Just ran 1 mile in 9 minutes. First time I've jogged or ran since my accident on April 21st. Man it felt good to go faster than a fast walk pace!

June 16
Had a meeting with thumb doc and all is well. The last fracture is going to heal on its own and I'm permitted to resume all normal activities aside from firmly and harshly pressing down with my thumb. So that is great news, full range of movement is getting better!

July 19
11 weeks to the day post-surgery and I'm feeling great. 2 wheelie attempts didn't feel awesome so I'll continue to rest until my late August x-ray! But overall glad to be back on the bike!

July 20
First epic ride out with my boy on the greenway. No sending for me. Ha! Felt incredible to be out!!

August 22
Nearly 4 months post-surgery and the doc has cleared me to ride. Just don't fall is the advice! Ha! Another 6 to 8 weeks for a fully healed clavicle, but it's good enough. The titanium bar is strong enough that my bone shouldn't break without a major impact which I hope to avoid.

item.title: My MTB Sends
item.dc:creator: ssbitsadmin
item.content:encoded:
I've got some of my favorite sends on video. There's a few more that I might consider in my top 10, but this is a pretty good list.


Red Bull Drop at Windrock in Oliver Springs, TN
By far, this has to be one of the most epic checkboxes of my short MTB career. It involves the rockiest, steepest, fastest terrain I'd ever ridden. Not to mention the biggest drop and jumps.


Southeast Style at Ride Kanuga in Hendersonville, NC
Massive 30+ jumps at 30+MPH speeds.


Tombstone at Ride Kanuga in Hendersonville, NC
Black diamond jump line that I must have been insane to attempt.


Drop The Hammer at Coler Preserve in Bentonville, AR
The biggest drop and set of features I'd ever done at the time, this will forever rank up there as one of my top sends!


Stampede at Rock Creek in Zirconia, NC
I haven't quite put the whole thing together and may never, but some of these features (like the road gap) on this pro line are on my forever checkbox list.


Black Mamba Drop at Beech Mountain in Beech Mountain, NC
This double black line has a massive drop into a berm that looks like you're sending it off into the abyss. Very scary.


ECR Rock Roll at Sugar Mountain in Sugar Mountain, NC
This massive rock roll is insane and so thrilling!!


Dark Hollow at Rock Creek in Zirconia, NC
I wasn't sure if I could do the road gap, but nailing this whole black diamond tech line was satisfying and ranks up there at the top of my list.


Hemloch Epoch at Ride Kanuga in Hendersonville, NC
It took me forever, but I finally nailed the treacherous double after the gap jump on this black diamond tech line.


Roll The Dice at Berm Park in Canton, NC
Fun quick jump line with epic wall features!


Nervous Breakdown at Cedar Valley Bike Park in Davidson, NC
This pro line is filled with huge 20+' mandatory doubles and a large road drop/gap.


Free Ride Line at Back Yard Trails in Charlotte, NC
This line started it all. It's a very tough tight trail in the woods near the sewage treatment plant. Filled with poison ivy and a dangerous creek gap, you do not want to wreck! It took me a couple of years to work up the nerve and skill to check this box off.
